messageBody:
I think it's an idiom and all idioms look strange when you first see
them. Then they look normal.

The empty catch doesn't bother me, because all rules have exceptions -
no pun intended :-). On distinguishing try/catches that test for
exceptions and ones that don't, I don't see a problem because I can't
imagine a sitution where I would want a try/catch in a unit test unless
I was using this idiom. I guess it's for the same reason that tests
shouldn't have conditionals in them: clear tests express a single path.

Michael Feathers
michaelfeathers.typepad.com
www.objectmentor.com


Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:

>Hi Stephen,
>
>Well, as you say, this is a subjective area, but I'll list some of the
>reasons why I think the first example is convoluted:
>
> - It's using a reverse logic: enter catch -> good, proceed as usual
> -> bad. This is highly counter-intuitive.
> - It has an empty catch statement (always a code smell in my book),
> hence the necessity to add a no-op call or a comment to say "it's okay, I
> know what I'm doing".
> - It doesn't express its intent clearly (if I show you three tests
> with try/catch, you won't be able to tell right away which ones test for
> exceptions and which ones don't).
>
>On the other hand, the annotated code expresses its intent clearly (it
>almost reads as plain English), doesn't drown the signal in noise and is
>much shorter.
>
>It's actually a perfect example where annotations are clearly an improvement
>over the "old way", in my opinion...
>
>
